results.title: Brown rot
results.creator_credit: J.V. Durden, Stephen Ackroyd and Shell Film Unit
results.brief_description: Shows the nature and extent of the fruit disease know as “brown rot”. Illustrations include initial infection of the fruit; development of the mycelium and fruit bearing bodies, conidiophores; growth rings found in the affected areas of the fruit; transfer of the disease from fruit to fruit.
results.creator_credit_for_label: J.V. Durden, Stephen Ackroyd and Shell Film Unit

results.title: Brown coal to kilowatts
results.creator_credit: Frank Hurley and State Electricity Commission of Victoria
results.brief_description: Classroom film describing the processes by which wet, raw brown coal from the Yallourn open cut is burned in specially designed boilers to produce steam for use in turbines for the generation of electric power. Laboratory demonstration, models, and diagrams explain the principles of operation of plant seen in use at Yallourn.

results.title: Brown coal to briquettes
results.creator_credit: Frank Hurley and State Electricity Commission of Victoria
results.brief_description: Classroom film showing the manufacture of briquettes at Yallourn and Morwell Victoria. Includes demonstration by models of processes; operation of coal dredges at open cut; crushing and drying of coal; pressing of fine powder into briquettes; transport of finished product to other parts of Victoria.

results.title: Brown bears go fishing
results.brief_description: This film aims to stimulate interest in reading and to increase the vocabulary of primary pupils by using over prints and repetition in the narration. While reading and looking at storybooks, a group of children learn about the habits of polar bears and American black bears. Shows Alaskan brown bears swimming in a stream, catching and eating salmon, fighting over fish and teaching cubs how to swim.

results.title: Brotherhood of man
results.creator_credit: Robert Cannon, Stephen Bosustow and United Productions of America
results.brief_description: This film was made as a contribution to “Brotherhood Week” held in the USA in 1946, in which President Truman called on Americans to see that fair practices were the rule in both private and industrial life. The film is based on the pamphlet “Races of Mankind”, written by Dr.Ruth Benedict and Gene Weltfish, anthropologists of Columbia University USA, and published in 1943. “Brotherhood of man” explodes a number of commonly held fallacies which lead to racial discrimination and group persecution. It gives a clear scientific exposition of a number of basic biological and historical facts, which demonstrate the fundamental identity of humanity, stressing the need for tolerance and co-operation between all groups and races since human beings are always dependent on other human beings. It uses humor rather than drama to make its points. The soundtrack of this film was translated and re-recorded for use by the USA Occupation forces in Europe.

results.title: Brother
results.creator_credit: Adam Elliot and Australian Film Commission
results.brief_description: Through the narration, we recall events in the lives of two young brothers growing up in the suburbs. We learn about “getting the blame” for things you didn’t do, and that if the devil doesn’t get you then karma will. Above all we see how two brothers deal with an alcoholic father, disease and asthma. Narrated by William McInnes. This clay animation film forms part of the autobiographical trilogy that includes “Uncle”, “Brother” and “Cousin”.

results.title: Bronze boy
results.creator_credit: David Sims, David H. Fowler, Geoffrey Scott and New Zealand National Film Unit
results.brief_description:
Episode number 228 of Series “Parade”.
A step-by-step record of the creation in 1969 of a life-sized statue of “Young Nick”, a cabin boy on Captain Cook’s ship “Endeavour”. The sculptor, Auckland’s Frank Szirmay, speaks about his work.

results.title: Brolga
results.brief_description: The life cycle of the brolga, Australia’s only red crane, also known as the native companion. Flocks gather in the early morning to feed on insects, rodents and herbage. About September the birds pair off for mating, after a strange courting dance, and raise two chicks, which soon learn to follow their parents around. At about four months they are big enough to fly and join the flock. The film includes a number of remarkable sequences, photographed in slow motion, recording brolgas in flight.

results.title: Broken Hill: a mining history 1883-1983
results.creator_credit: Terence McMahon, CRA, North Broken Hill Holdings and Terence McMahon Productions
results.brief_description: Provides a history of the Broken Hill mining industry from 1883 to the present day, incorporating documentary footage and stills of the early days, as well as comments by historian Geoffrey Blainey. Notes the early strike; the impact of technology and science in the 1920s and 30s; the mass production of fighter aircraft by BHP in the 1930s; the opening of the silver-lead smelter at Port Pirie and the steel industry at Newcastle; the introduction of company housing, health schemes and lead bonuses in the 1950s and 60s; and the intensive exploratory drilling’s for further ore deposits in the 1970s and 80s. Photography by David Olney. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: Broken highway [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Laurie McInnes, Richard Mason and Black Ray Films
results.brief_description: A group of sailors aboard a merchant ship gamble and booze their way towards the Australian Coast. Among them are handsome young Angel (Aden Young), a winner to every game that Tatt’s (David Field) loses. Max (Dennis Miller), an Ancient Mariner who is close to death, instructs Angel to deliver a package to his old home in Honeyfield, Queensland, the place he remembers as paradise. He also gives him a bag of opium to appease sinister landowner Kidd (Norman Kaye). What awaits Angel is far from the tropical paradise of Max’s recollecting, although the presence of an attractive woman, Catherine (Claudia Karvan), helps matters. To confound matters and add to the inhospitability of the place, Tatt’s arrives to settle to settle a score. Cast includes Bill Hunter, Dennis Miller and David Field.
